docs.snippet: For people on the go who don't want to buy bottled water, Brita, a company that makes charcoal filters for removing chlorine, odors and unpleasant flavors from water, has introduced a 20-ounce water bottle with a small carbon filter about the size...
docs.lead_paragraph: For people on the go who don't want to buy bottled water, Brita, a company that makes charcoal filters for removing chlorine, odors and unpleasant flavors from water, has introduced a 20-ounce water bottle with a small carbon filter about the size of a cigarette lighter in its cap. The plastic bottle has a blue push-pull cap and a spot to place a sticker to remind the user to replace the filter every hundred refills or so. The bottle is about $8 at housewares stores, and replacement filters are about $3.50.

headline.main: A Way for the Footloose To Filter Their Own Water

docs.snippet: The ice cream mix-ins at the new Petrossian Cafe and Boutique, 911 Seventh Avenue, a few steps from the restaurant on the corner of 58th Street, are a far cry from the usual. Passion fruit seeds, caraway seeds, orange zest, praline jelly and pista...
docs.lead_paragraph: The ice cream mix-ins at the new Petrossian Cafe and Boutique, 911 Seventh Avenue, a few steps from the restaurant on the corner of 58th Street, are a far cry from the usual. Passion fruit seeds, caraway seeds, orange zest, praline jelly and pistachios are arrayed in small containers on the bakery counter, where ice cream ($6 to $8 a portion), fruit tarts ($6), filled beignets ($6 for six) and layered coupes of cream, cake, jelly and mousse ($7 to $8) are assembled a la minute -- in two to four minutes -- while you wait. For the chef, Philippe Conticini, and the company's president, Armen Petrossian, freshness is paramount. The caramelized apple tart with riesling gelee is assembled and warmed just before serving, so that the crisp pastry shell does not become soggy. The vanilla ice cream is churned fresh, order by order. Classic French pastries like gat eau St.-Honore must be ordered in advance.

headline.main: Pastries Built on the Spot, Ice Cream Mixed to Order and, of Course, Caviar

docs.snippet: Residents of the financial district have had few options when it comes to stocking the pantry, so Vine Market, 25 Broad Street (Exchange Place), should be a welcome addition. It's in the Exchange Building, a century-old landmark converted into mor...
docs.abstract: Vine Market, new food store, serves residents of New York City's financial district; photo (Food Stuff column) (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Residents of the financial district have had few options when it comes to stocking the pantry, so Vine Market, 25 Broad Street (Exchange Place), should be a welcome addition. It's in the Exchange Building, a century-old landmark converted into more than 300 apartments, and it is connected to Vine, a small new restaurant. The airy market is run by Nancy Hart, who was the catering manager at the Vinegar Factory and Eli's Manhattan uptown. She offers a selection of attractive items, including smoked fish, fine cheeses, bread from Tom Cat Bakery and Amy's Bread, pastries by Sarabeth's and City Bakery and a good selection of produce and high-quality olive oils, vinegars and other condiments. The market also stocks some ingredients for baking, as well as paper goods and detergents.

headline.main: If Wall Street Crumbles, It Won't Starve

docs.snippet: What's new in potato chips? The color blue, a deep purply blue rimmed with lavender, in fact. They are from Olive Oil Potato Chips, which makes delicious crisp chips from potatoes fried in olive oil and seasoned with sea salt and rosemary, black p...
docs.abstract: Olive Oil Potato Chips offers blue chips made from blue potatoes; photo (Food Stuff column) (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: What's new in potato chips? The color blue, a deep purply blue rimmed with lavender, in fact. They are from Olive Oil Potato Chips, which makes delicious crisp chips from potatoes fried in olive oil and seasoned with sea salt and rosemary, black pepper or garlic. The blue chips, made from blue potatoes, have an earthy flavor with hints of celery. Try them with a dip made with a half cup each of mayonnaise and plain yogurt. Add a large stalk of celery grated fine in a food processor, a tablespoon of minced dill and two to three tablespoons of prepared horseradish. This yields one and a half cups of dip, which should be enough for a five-ounce bag of the chips. The chips are $4.95 in many food shops.

docs.snippet: Large-scale food irradiation probably makes sense as a safety precaution, but it’s not likely to happen....
docs.abstract: Large-scale food irradiation probably makes sense as a safety precaution, but it’s not likely to happen.
docs.lead_paragraph: After the E. coli outbreak in Europe last month — which sickened more than 3000 people and killed at least 50 — it was impossible not to think about irradiation. “What if,” I asked myself, “those little fenugreek seeds had been irradiated?” Might there have been fewer deaths, fewer cases of hemolytic-uremic syndrome (essentially, kidney failure; there were 900), fewer tragic stories?

docs.snippet: A report released yesterday by the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene found that residents in East and Central Harlem have far less access to healthful food in stores than their nearby counterparts on the Upper East Side. The rep...

byline.original: By MANHATTAN: HARLEM FOOD SHOPS CHIDED

docs.lead_paragraph: A report released yesterday by the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene found that residents in East and Central Harlem have far less access to healthful food in stores than their nearby counterparts on the Upper East Side. The report, based on a survey that department researchers conducted in 2005, found that stores in Harlem were half as likely to stock low-fat dairy products and seven times less likely to sell common vegetables, said Andrew Tucker, a Health Department spokesman. Mr. Tucker said city officials were working with store owners to encourage them to offer more healthful foods.

docs.snippet: For decades, when restaurants were buying, not serving, meat in the meatpacking district, DeBragga & Spitler was dedicated to accommodating New York's top chefs. Marc Sarrazin, a French butcher who became the president of the company in 1973, had ...
docs.abstract: DeBragga & Spitler butchers purveyor to New York City's top chefs, have begun selling to retail customers through company's new Web site debragga.com; photo (Food Stuff column) (S)
docs.news_desk: Dining In, Dining Out / Style Desk
docs.lead_paragraph: For decades, when restaurants were buying, not serving, meat in the meatpacking district, DeBragga & Spitler was dedicated to accommodating New York's top chefs. Marc Sarrazin, a French butcher who became the president of the company in 1973, had his finger on the pulse of the New York restaurant world, as adviser and friend as well as purveyor. His son, Marc John, joined him about 15 years ago, and in 2006 George W. Faison, a founder of D'Artagnan, became a partner. Several months ago the company began selling to retail customers through its new Web site, www.debragga.com, where restaurant-quality beef, lamb, pork, veal, poultry and sausages are sold. Especially worth noting are high-quality grass-fed beef strip loins (four 12-ounce steaks for $54.95; four 16-ounce ones, $73.95). They're deeply flavorful and though they are not quite as buttery as the company's dry-aged prime strip loins, they are about a third the price.

headline.main: Top Chefs Buy Here, Now You Can, Too

docs.snippet: Brightening the bar at Madaleine Mae, a restaurant that opened yesterday on the Upper West Side, are about a dozen bottles with colorful fabric caps. They hold herbs, spices, fruit and rum, or rhum, as it is called on Guadeloupe, the Caribbean isl...
docs.abstract: Bar at newly-opened Madaleine Mae restaurant in Manhattan is serving concoctions from Guadeloupe (Food Stuff column) (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Brightening the bar at Madaleine Mae, a restaurant that opened yesterday on the Upper West Side, are about a dozen bottles with colorful fabric caps. They hold herbs, spices, fruit and rum, or rhum, as it is called on Guadeloupe, the Caribbean island that inspired these concoctions. Doug Quinn, right, the beverage director for the restaurant's owner, the Clarke's Group, spent a couple of weeks on the island, learning the secrets of these elixirs, or ''cures,'' as he calls them.

headline.main: Serious or Sexy, A Rhum's the Thing

docs.snippet: Wine sets the scene at Alain Ducasse's restaurant in the St. Regis, Adour Alain Ducasse, which is to open on Monday. David Rockwell, the designer, said he studied glasses of Burgundy to select the dining room's dominant color. Chardonnay-gold acce...
docs.news_desk: Dining In, Dining Out / Style Desk
docs.lead_paragraph: Wine sets the scene at Alain Ducasse's restaurant in the St. Regis, Adour Alain Ducasse, which is to open on Monday. David Rockwell, the designer, said he studied glasses of Burgundy to select the dining room's dominant color. Chardonnay-gold accents lighten the somewhat clubby look. Glass-front wine storage units are positioned around the room, and there are four decanting stations for the sommeliers. Thomas Combescot-Lepère, the wine director, has been working with Tony Esnault, the executive chef, to select wine-friendly dishes like Berkshire pork given an earthy edge with black truffles, and lobster thermidor with an intensified sauce friendly to red wine, so that a party of four, each ordering a different main course, can choose a bottle that's compatible with everything. Above, Mr. Combescot-Lepère checks for sediment as he decants a bottle.

headline.main: For Alain Ducasse, A Dining Room Drenched in Wine
